title: 114_hr5107
content: The Act titled "Social Networking Online Protection Act" prohibits employer access to personal accounts on social networking websites. The "Social Networking Online Protection Act" prohibits employers from requesting passwords for private email or personal online accounts and from taking adverse actions against employees who refuse to provide access. The Act prohibits employers from requesting passwords for private online accounts and taking adverse actions against employees who refuse. Employers who violate the Act may face civil penalties of up to $10,000, with penalties determined based on compliance history and the severity of the violation. Penalties will be collected in a similar manner as outlined in the Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act. The Secretary of Labor may take legal action to enforce the Act, including obtaining restraining orders and injunctions for compliance, reinstatement, and payment of wages. SEC. 3. INSTITUTION OF HIGHER EDUCATION ACCESS TO PERSONAL ACCOUNTS ON SOCIAL NETWORKING WEBSITES. Section 487(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to prohibit institutions from requesting access to students' private email or online accounts, including social networking sites, and from taking adverse actions against students who refuse to provide such access. The amendment to Section 487(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 prohibits institutions from requesting access to students' private email or online accounts, including social networking sites, if the student has filed a complaint or testified in a related proceeding. The term "social networking website" is defined as per the Social Networking Online Protection Act. SEC. 9537 prohibits access to personal accounts of students on social networking websites by local educational agencies. Local educational agencies cannot require students to provide passwords for private email or personal online accounts, including social networking sites. They also cannot take adverse actions against students who refuse to provide this information or who file complaints. The subsection defines "social networking website" and makes a clerical amendment to the table of contents for the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "employer" refers to any person acting in the interest of an employer in relation to an employee or applicant for employment. A "social networking website" is an Internet service that provides a user with a distinct account for uploading, storing, and managing personal content.
